thread.title: Luke Bryan is dangerously hot
thread.title_full: Luke Bryan is dangerously hot - San Antonio Express-News

author: John Goodspeed
title: Luke Bryan is dangerously hot
text:
Photo: Billy Calzada, Staff / San Antonio Express-News Image 1 of / 8 8 Country singer Luke Bryan sings for a sellout crowd at the San Antonio AT&T Center on Thursday, September 18, 2014. Country singer Luke Bryan sings for a sellout crowd at the San Antonio AT&T Center on Thursday, September 18, 2014. Photo: Billy Calzada, Staff / San Antonio Express-News Image 2 of 8 Luke Bryan’s “Kick Up the Dust” tour rolls into the Alamodome on Thursday night with Randy Houser and Dustin Lynch as the opening acts. Luke Bryan’s “Kick Up the Dust” tour rolls into the Alamodome on Thursday night with Randy Houser and Dustin Lynch as the opening acts. Photo: Melissa Phillip /Houston Chronicle Image 3 of 8 Luke Bryan performs during RodeoHouston at the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo in NRG Stadium Sunday, March 22, 2015, in Houston. ( Melissa Phillip / Houston Chronicle ) Luke Bryan performs during RodeoHouston at the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo in NRG Stadium Sunday, March 22, 2015, in Houston. ( Melissa Phillip / Houston Chronicle ) Photo: Melissa Phillip, Staff / Houston Chronicle Image 4 of 8 Luke Bryan performs during RodeoHouston at the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo in NRG Stadium Sunday, March 22, 2015, in Houston. ( Melissa Phillip / Houston Chronicle ) Luke Bryan performs during RodeoHouston at the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo in NRG Stadium Sunday, March 22, 2015, in Houston. ( Melissa Phillip / Houston Chronicle ) Photo: Melissa Phillip, Staff / Houston Chronicle Image 5 of 8 Dustin Lynch performs at 8 Second Saloon on March 8, 2013 in Indianapolis, Indiana. (Photo by Joey Foley/Getty Images) Dustin Lynch performs at 8 Second Saloon on March 8, 2013 in Indianapolis, Indiana. (Photo by Joey Foley/Getty Images) Photo: Joey Foley, Contributor / Getty Images Image 6 of 8 Spring Breakers enjoy Luke Bryan's annual free concert at Spinnaker Beach Club on Wednesday, March 11, 2015, in Panama City Beach, Fla. (AP Photo/News Herald, Heather Leiphart) Spring Breakers enjoy Luke Bryan's annual free concert at Spinnaker Beach Club on Wednesday, March 11, 2015, in Panama City Beach, Fla. (AP Photo/News Herald, Heather Leiphart) Photo: Heather Leiphart, MBO / Associated Press Image 7 of 8 LAS VEGAS, NV - DECEMBER 10: Recording artist Randy Houser performs onstage during the 2013 American Country Awards at the Mandalay Bay Events Center on December 10, 2013 in Las Vegas, Nevada. (Photo by Ethan Miller/Getty Images) LAS VEGAS, NV - DECEMBER 10: Recording artist Randy Houser performs onstage during the 2013 American Country Awards at the Mandalay Bay Events Center on December 10, 2013 in Las Vegas, Nevada. (Photo by ... more Photo: Ethan Miller, Staff / Getty Images Image 8 of 8 Luke Bryan is dangerously hot 1 / 8 Back to Gallery Forget it if there’s any doubt that Luke Bryan ’s career has skyrocketed into the league of the superstar — for country or any other genre.
Sure, he’s the reigning entertainer of the year of the Academy of Country Music and the Country Music Association , and up again for that honor at the CMA awards Nov. 4.
But his fame also crowns Bryan with a dubious distinction — the second most-dangerous celebrity on the Internet, just 3/10ths of a point behind Armin van Buuren , the Dutch deejay and trance music producer.
Searches online for van Buuren and Bryan put web surfers at a risk of 17.92 percent and 17.64 percent respectively of landing on a site that carries viruses or malware that can lead to theft of passwords and personal information, according to Intel Security, which announced its ninth annual list earlier this month.
More Information Vital info
When: 7:30 p.m. Thursday
Where: Alamodome, 100 Montana St.
Tickets: $30.25-$60.25, ticketmaster.com
Park & Ride: Service from AT&T Center starting at 5 p.m. Thursday; $5 round trip, viainfo.net
For openers
Randy Houser left touring in his native state of Mississippi in 2002 for a songwriting gig in Nashville, landing recordings by the likes of Trace Adkins with “Honky Tonk Badonkadonk.” He decided to sing his own songs and scored big with his third album, 2013’s “How Country Feels,” which launched a run of four Top 5 singles with three consecutive No. 1s — “How Country Feels,” “Runnin’ Outta Moonlight” and “Goodnight Kiss.” Houser is nominated for a CMA song of the year for the ballad “Like a Cowboy.” He will kick off his first headlining arena tour in November.
Dustin Lynch: Luke Bryan may be looking over his shoulder at Lynch, who won praise from Rolling Stone as his “possible heir apparent.” The Tennessee native’s self-titled debut album hit No. 1 on Billboard’s country chart when it was released in 2012. His debut single, “Cowboys and Angels,” also went to No. 1. Lynch is still on a roll with his sophomore album, last year’s “Where It’s At,” which boasts more than 1 million in sales of downloaded tracks. Last month, the rocking “Hell of a Night” became the second consecutive No. 1 from “Where It’s At,” following the title song. He will headline his first tour in November.
John Goodspeed
Usher, Britney Spears and Jay-Z round out the Top 5, according to an Associated Press report.
But wait — there’s more.
Superstars also can cause traffic jams like the one earlier this month before Bryan’s concert at a winery in Lexington, Kentucky.
Vehicles were backed up nearly eight miles, and many of them ran out of gas, according to the Lexington Herald-Leader. Some folks just pulled over and walked. Of course, it was just a two-lane road, and Bryan delayed the show to wait for fans.
A lot more roads, though, lead to the Alamodome , where Bryan will bring his Kick Up the Dust Tour at 7:30 p.m. Thursday with Randy Houser and Dustin Lynch.
Just in case, VIA Metropolitan Transit will offer special event park-and-ride service from the AT&T Center beginning at 5 p.m. Thursday with return buses running for one hour after the end of the show. Round-trip fare is $5 with the usual discounts available.
VIA also will divert Route 100 Primo into the Robert Thompson Transit Station at the Alamodome from 5 p.m. until one hour after the concert. The fare is $1.20. Call 210-362-2020.
The Kick Up the Dust Tour is named for Bryan’s lead single from his fifth studio album, “Kill the Lights,” released in August. “Kick Up the Dust,” his 13th No. 1, topped charts the same week the album debuted at No. 1 on Billboard’s country and Top 200 charts — his third consecutive No. 1 on the all-genre chart.
The second single, “Strip It Down,” currently tops Billboard’s country chart.
“Kill the Lights” is the highest country album debut in two years, since Bryan’s “Crash My Party” in August 2013.
“Crash My Party” also produced six consecutive No. 1 singles, including “I See You,” “Drink a Beer” and “Play It Again,” and sold more than 2 million copies and 8 million downloads.
The tour, which began May 8 in Grand Forks, North Dakota, will end Oct. 30 at Ford Field in Detroit. That show sold out the day that tickets went on sale, marking the 10th sold-out stadium concert on the tour so far.
In 2013, Bryan’s first major headlining tour played before 1.3 million fans. Last year, the total jumped to 1.7 million.
Bryan even is the focus of an exhibit at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville. “Luke Bryan: Dirt Road Diary,” which runs through Nov. 8, includes memorabilia such as his Little League baseball uniform, his first guitar, which his parents gave him when he was 14, and bows and arrows he used on the Outdoor Channel series “Buck Commander: Protected by Under Armour.”
Bryan grew up on the family farm in Leesburg, Georgia, where his father grew peanuts and sold fertilizer, listening to George Strait , Alan Jackson and Conway Twitty.
After college at Georgia Southern University , he left the farm for Nashville, where he landed a song publishing contract and later a recording deal with Capitol Records.
His debut album in 2007, “I’ll Stay Me,” spawned the Top 5 single “All My Friends Say.” His neo-traditional country style spiced with party-hearty, rocking pop-country caught fire.
Two years later, his sophomore album “Doin’ My Thing” hit No. 2 on the charts and produced two No. 1 singles - “Rain Is a Good Thing” and “Someone Else Calling You Baby.”
His third album, “Tailgates & Tanlines,” led to two more No. 1s and two Top 5s. “Spring Break … Here to Party” in 2013 fanned the flames with more hits.
“Crash My Party” led to superstardom — and Internet infamy as a dangerous celebrity. Still, he stays grounded and tries to show it in his latest album, he told The Tennessean.
“I wanted to show moments of maturing. That has to be there. That's what's going on in my life,” he told the Nashville newspaper. “But I also can’t run from the fact that when I look out into a crowd, what my fans are.
“I am absolutely amazed when 16-year-old girls jump out of a car and run up to me wanting a picture.”
john@johngoodspeed.com
